data.title: Text Highlighting error when using \": in json data
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1607

Steps to Reproduce:
the following JS code does not highlight as expected
```
var test = {
    "data": "\number\":8"
}

var test2 = "text is correct still, but everything else is light blue"
var testfunc = function() {
    //this is not working as expected
}
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/823986/28430880-197ab98e-6d50-11e7-97e3-261b5952634c.png)

if you remove the colon, or the \" it will work as expected:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/823986/28430942-6d2f8d7a-6d50-11e7-90b9-9c9029e92450.png)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
No extensions installed, fresh install of the vscode on a new pc.

data.title: Duality between single-folder workspaces and multi-folder workspaces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I looked at the multi-root workspace implementation and noticed that the internal API differentiates between a "single-folder workspace" (an opened folder) and a "multi-folder workspace" (a workspace with possibly multiple roots that can be persisted to a file). Depending on the kind of workspace, different code paths are taken in multiple places.

When a user has a folder open and wants to add a second one, he is prompted with this dialog:

![Upgrade Workspace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/28367923-f06008be-6c92-11e7-8c53-bd07f0a7cc56.png)

This makes the UX heavier than in e.g. Sublime, where you can just open a single folder, then drag-and-drop other folders to add them to the workspace without having to reload.

New "multi-folder" workspace already don't need to be explicitely saved in VS Code, there is a concept of an untitled workspace and VS Code is able to restore even untitled workspaces from a previous session.

I am wondering whether it would be easier to not differentiate between "single-folder" and "multi-folder", but let single-folder just be an untitled workspace with a single folder in it. That way
- a user could add more folders without having to "upgrade" the workspace and reload
- the internal API becomes a lot simpler (smaller bug area, e.g. #31142)

Users who don't want to use multi-folder workspaces would not notice the change. The single folder would always be opened in the "default" untitled workspace. File -> Open Folder would just replace the `roots` array with a new array that only contains the new folder. This would also provide the ability to change folders completely without reloading the window once extensions handle the `onDidChangeWorkspaceRoots` event.

Would love to hear your thoughts!

data.title: Settings view: Focus moves from active buffer to searchbar after executing command
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (3cfa565abbd6e162b7ae6f3055c231128da63df2, 2017-07-17T05:07:20.317Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: Reproduces without extensions.

![vscode-insiders-settings-focus](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2955510/28428795-5b00fd58-6d2f-11e7-8615-028b2258c20f.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the Settings view (`âŒ˜ + ,`).
2. Focus one of the buffers ("User Settings", "Workspace Settings", etc).
3. Run a command through the Command Palette (e.g., `Sort Lines Ascending`).

Expected result:

- Command executes and focus remains in the active buffer.

Actual result:

- Command executes and focus is moved to the Settings searchbar.

Is this by design?

data.title: keytar Linux 32bit
data.body:
Building keytar for Linux 32bit using a separate Docker container run inside the build agent.

I have added the following to `docker run` in `vso-start-agent`: `-e WORK_MNT="/mnt/work/tb-lnx-$i" -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock`. Not sure where that file's source is held.

This is a 'one off' solution for keytar, but could certainly expanded to include more. Having a Dockerfile that is built each time (and usually cached) makes it easy to update.

data.title: Fix multi-workspace support detection
data.body:
Noticed this always evaluated to `true` because it didn't call the method, only checked for its presence. Also renamed it to a verb so it's more obvious this is a method.
The condition inside `isSupported()` was also inversed

data.title: Launch configuration with npm preLaunchTask fails
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f5c4b7abd3188b51883a6a4ab30d73d2ade2af63, 2017-07-20T08:30:48.273Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: none
---

#### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add a script to a `package.json` file or add a npm task to `tasks.json` with or without an identifier.
2. Create a launch configuration with a `preLaunchTask` that attempts to run it.

#### Expected result:
Debugger should launch.

#### Actual result:
`Could not find the preLaunchTask 'build'`

#### Notes:
- Used variations on the task name such as `npm: build`, with and without spaces/symbols, to no effect.
- Setting the `preLaunchTask` to gulp and shell tasks works correctly.
- Developer console contains:

data.title: Windows - search result resource path is incorrect in multi root folder setup
data.body:
Happens on Windows only.

- in multi root folder setup search for a pattern using "Find in Folder"
- open the result from the search result view
-> the path to the resource is not correct, the volume name is missing (see below). As a consequence the workbench opens this file as an external file.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28419817-886ca02c-6d60-11e7-8479-bf91a9cd800a.png)

It could show something like "Executing task npm install in PATH"

data.title: Introduce an API in IWorkspaceContextService to know the state of the workspace
Credentials API
data.body:
We will offer extension API around keytar such that extensions can use the host OS secret store. Current proposal is:

```ts
	/**
	 * Namespace for handling credentials.
	 */
	export namespace credentials {

		/**
		 * Read a previously stored secret from the credential store.
		 *
		 * @param service The service of the credential.
		 * @param account The account of the credential.
		 * @return A promise for the secret of the credential.
		 */
		export function readSecret(service: string, account: string): Thenable<string | undefined>;

		/**
		 * Write a secret to the credential store.
		 *
		 * @param service The service of the credential.
		 * @param account The account of the credential.
		 * @param secret The secret of the credential to write to the credential store.
		 * @return A promise indicating completion of the operation.
		 */
		export function writeSecret(service: string, account: string, secret: string): Thenable<void>;

		/**
		 * Delete a previously stored secret from the credential store.
		 *
		 * @param service The service of the credential.
		 * @param account The account of the credential.
		 * @return A promise resolving to true if there was a secret for that service and account.
		 */
		export function deleteSecret(service: string, account: string): Thenable<boolean>;
	}
```

data.title: API: Window state
data.body:
This will allow me to address #11918

Introduced `ExtHostWindow` et al, due to the lack of a better option of putting these properties.

Question: should the `onDidChangeWindowFocus` event have a better type for the event message, other than plain `boolean`?

Fixes #18263

data.title: Installer Not Using Windows "Restart Manager" ?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Absolutely loving Visual Studio Code!  The installation experience on Windows - not so much.

I haven't dug through the MSI, but the dialog in this screenshot seems to indicate that this package has not been authored to enable MSI to use Windows built-in "Restart Manager" functionality.

It does not seem to matter what I choose on this dialog, the results seem unexpected and bad - compared to most MSI packages I've run over the last decade.

I believe the lack of using this core Windows platform feature is the reason for many of the other "installer" issues that have been opened.

If this package is indeed not leveraging MSI's ability to use Restart Manager, here is the starting point: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa372466(v=vs.85).aspx

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11597190/28416684-0a02a2d2-6d23-11e7-9c4e-6b53966adca1.png)

data.title: Snippet variable text isn't whitespace normalised
data.body:
* have a snippet like this `
\n\t$TM_SELECTED_TEXT\n
$0` * select indented text on two lines * insert that snippet * :bug: the second line of the selection isn't correctly indented. This is because we normalise whitespace *before* parsing and snippet resolving: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/snippet/browser/snippetSession.ts#L291 ![jul-20-2017 12-47-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1794099/28413922-9fc04dee-6d49-11e7-9a66-6124087d14f6.gif)

data.title: [json] Cache JSON schemas locally

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
At the moment I'm travelling and it's not 100% of the time that I have an internet connection.
Turns out that vscode does not cache JSON schemas that are defined in URLs, I presume, here:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/ac8f47b193f08b93e0d05201cf3ecc896914e6a5/extensions/typescript/package.json#L447

It's a pitty that JSON schema for sure did not change since an hour ago, when I had the internet connection, but I have zero completion for `tsconfig.json` right now, just because I'm offline.

Therefore, it would be super amazing to have JSON schemas cached if the URL did not change.
